Helpfully, and lucratively, they positioned themselves as the brand to sport if you want to signal that you’re a believer of racial equality. Sales went up 31% after Nike aired their Colin Kaepernick ad. They weren’t selling their merchandise, they were selling us a better idea of ourselves, with Nike. And it worked. Curiously, perfume and cologne ads rarely if ever bother to describe the scent they’re selling. They’ll show you a sleek bottle and an even sleeker model, but they’re blatantly not trying to sell you what the perfume smells like. And it works — fragrance is a 75.6 billion dollar industry as of 2019. The ads don’t describe if it’s floral, sweet, musky. They don’t even show you the model, celebrity, or other beautiful person putting on the perfume. Perfume ads just show you Charlize Theron slinking towards the camera seductively, dressed all in gold. In short, perfume ads are the most obvious example of lifestyle marketing, because you can’t sell a smell on TV. Instead, they’re selling you what you’ll have if you buy this perfume. Sex. Youth. Power. Influence. And those all can easily become highly visual imagery, to which we’re imminently susceptible. When you see a perfume ad whether on a bus or a television, you’re not being sold a smell. Instead, perfume ads are evoking some of the most primal, desperate emotions in you and cloaking it as a scent you should buy. This ad above, with Jennifer Lawrence selling Dior’s JOY, doesn’t actually show you the perfume bottle (pink, cylindrical) until the last three seconds. The only reason I knew it was perfume was because it followed to the letter the script we’ve come to expect. There’s a lot of Lawrence swanning about on a floaty, biting into a ripe plum. She dives into a pool wearing a white, poufy dress. Underwater, she reaches out to try and touch an improbably-placed jellyfish. Her gaze slowly travels across the screen at one point before staring directly into the camera, skewering us in our seats. It’s scintillating, a study in innocence and carelessness and serendipity. Lawrence is ever-so-carefully sexy as well — not too sexy, which would ruin the innocence, but just sexy enough to give us a voyeuristic sense as we watch her gambolling. Buy this perfume, the ad whispers to us, and you too can be light and carefree, untouched by others’ expectations of you, unburdened by petty obligations. Buy this perfume and feel true joy. None of that has to do with the smell. Perfume ads say more about us than them. You can learn a lot from perfume ads, but more as a study in introspection than anything else. Watch some and see which ones appeal to you. What colors do they use? What emotions do they try to evoke in you? Which ones strike deepest into your secret desires? When you start to recognize the type of imagery perfume ads are actually selling, you’ll be struck by how blatant it is. They’re not subtle about it, they’re just relying on you to be so caught up with the desire to be desirable that you’ll miss that they haven’t actually sold you any perfume. Perfumers, to be successful, need a deep and comprehensive knowledge about what makes people want . After all, they’re able to sell a smell by showing us a completely unrelated image and getting us to relate the two in our minds, irreversibly. Simply by showing us pretty people dancing in slow motion and seductively looking into the camera, they’ve captured the essence of everything we strive for: inclusion, desirability, eternal youth, happiness without consequence. If you want to understand more about human nature, just look at perfume ads.
title_html: How Perfume Ads Sell You Sex, Not Smell
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

How Perfume Ads Sell You Sex, Not Smell

The psychological way fragrance ads trick you into buying their scents.

Zulie Rane
Apr 22

Humans, by and large, are primarily visual creatures. We’re one of the few primates to develop an extra colour receptor in our eyes; seeing emotional reactions in others causes us to feel them; and our eyes are comparatively the keenest of our senses.

This is why visual advertising works so well. We look at a picture of a big, juicy burger and our mouths start watering. We’re shown a video of a sad orangutan and our hearts melt. Visual advertising goes straight into our eyes and starts pushing all the relevant buttons in our brains.

However, most marketing takes advantage of a different sense: our sense of self.

How can you advertise a sense of self?

Nike ads, for example, recently have taken a turn to the political, causing ex-Nike fans to destroy their merchandise in droves.

But they’re causing even more people to think, if I need to buy running shoes, and I want to let everyone know what a free-thinking liberal I am, and actually a fierce warrior in the pursuit of justice, and socially aware of our community’s racial troubles — I’ll buy a pair of Nikes.

Nike are aware of the political battleground, and they’re aware that most of us don’t want to actually fight — we just want an easy way to say we’re the right kind of people, but without having to deal with any confrontation. Helpfully, and lucratively, they positioned themselves as the brand to sport if you want to signal that you’re a believer of racial equality.

Sales went up 31% after Nike aired their Colin Kaepernick ad. They weren’t selling their merchandise, they were selling us a better idea of ourselves, with Nike. And it worked.

But this was a pretty rare departure from their typical strategy. Normally, they use their product as a launching point to sell us what we really want: better versions of ourselves. We’ll see celebrities decked out in Nike merchandise — ostensibly selling us the shoe, but in reality selling us the lifestyle.

Perfume as a lifestyle.

Perfume is a different matter, because what you’re selling on the surface is a smell, which by nature cannot be conveyed via an image. The best you can do is try to describe it.

Curiously, perfume and cologne ads rarely if ever bother to describe the scent they’re selling. They’ll show you a sleek bottle and an even sleeker model, but they’re blatantly not trying to sell you what the perfume smells like. And it works — fragrance is a 75.6 billion dollar industry as of 2019.

The ads don’t describe if it’s floral, sweet, musky. They don’t even show you the model, celebrity, or other beautiful person putting on the perfume. Perfume ads just show you Charlize Theron slinking towards the camera seductively, dressed all in gold.

In short, perfume ads are the most obvious example of lifestyle marketing, because you can’t sell a smell on TV. Instead, they’re selling you what you’ll have if you buy this perfume. Sex. Youth. Power. Influence.

And those all can easily become highly visual imagery, to which we’re imminently susceptible.

When you see a perfume ad whether on a bus or a television, you’re not being sold a smell. Instead, perfume ads are evoking some of the most primal, desperate emotions in you and cloaking it as a scent you should buy.

This ad above, with Jennifer Lawrence selling Dior’s JOY, doesn’t actually show you the perfume bottle (pink, cylindrical) until the last three seconds. The only reason I knew it was perfume was because it followed to the letter the script we’ve come to expect.

There’s a lot of Lawrence swanning about on a floaty, biting into a ripe plum. She dives into a pool wearing a white, poufy dress. Underwater, she reaches out to try and touch an improbably-placed jellyfish. Her gaze slowly travels across the screen at one point before staring directly into the camera, skewering us in our seats.

It’s scintillating, a study in innocence and carelessness and serendipity. Lawrence is ever-so-carefully sexy as well — not too sexy, which would ruin the innocence, but just sexy enough to give us a voyeuristic sense as we watch her gambolling.

Buy this perfume, the ad whispers to us, and you too can be light and carefree, untouched by others’ expectations of you, unburdened by petty obligations. Buy this perfume and feel true joy.

None of that has to do with the smell.

Perfume ads say more about us than them.

You can learn a lot from perfume ads, but more as a study in introspection than anything else. Watch some and see which ones appeal to you. What colors do they use? What emotions do they try to evoke in you? Which ones strike deepest into your secret desires?

When you start to recognize the type of imagery perfume ads are actually selling, you’ll be struck by how blatant it is. They’re not subtle about it, they’re just relying on you to be so caught up with the desire to be desirable that you’ll miss that they haven’t actually sold you any perfume.

Perfumers, to be successful, need a deep and comprehensive knowledge about what makes people want. After all, they’re able to sell a smell by showing us a completely unrelated image and getting us to relate the two in our minds, irreversibly.

Simply by showing us pretty people dancing in slow motion and seductively looking into the camera, they’ve captured the essence of everything we strive for: inclusion, desirability, eternal youth, happiness without consequence. If you want to understand more about human nature, just look at perfume ads.

  • Perfume
  • Psychology
  • Self
  • Marketing
  • Culture

  • Zulie Rane

    Medium member since Mar 2019

    Lover of writing, mother of cats. Prone to trying psychological self help hacks. She/her.

  • Psychobabbling

    Getting your brain to do what you want it to.

    Getting your brain to do what you want it to.
title: How Perfume Ads Sell You Sex, Not Smell

How Perfume Ads Sell You Sex, Not Smell

The psychological way fragrance ads trick you into buying their scents.

Zulie Rane
Apr 22

Humans, by and large, are primarily visual creatures. We’re one of the few primates to develop an extra colour receptor in our eyes; seeing emotional reactions in others causes us to feel them; and our eyes are comparatively the keenest of our senses.

You can learn a lot from perfume ads, but more as a study in introspection than anything else. Watch some and see which ones appeal to you. What colors do they use? What emotions do they try to evoke in you? Which ones strike deepest into your secret desires?

Simply by showing us pretty people dancing in slow motion and seductively looking into the camera, they’ve captured the essence of everything we strive for: inclusion, desirability, eternal youth, happiness without consequence.
